Comment.MultiLanguageText: Analog Output Signal — raw range and configuration data
Analog Output Signal — scaled range and configuration data
Actual Output (as an integer for output card)
Signal Fault - Out of Range (either over or under)

AttributeList.Text: PRACTICAL SERIES AUTOMATION LIBRARY (PAL) — COPYRIGHT 2020 – M. GLEDHILL (MIT LICENCE) ———— ◆ ———— FULL ONLINE DOCUMENTATION IS AVAILABLE AT: https://practicalseries.com/2001-pal/index.html

▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ ＳＴＡＮＤＡＲＤ ▄▄
TITLE: SUBROUTINE — ANALOG OUTPUT SCALE
▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀
┌──────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ FC18002 — SOFTWARE MODULE DESIGN SPECIFICATION (SMDS) │ │ │ │ The PDF version of the SMDS for this module is available online here: │ │ https://psop.uk/pal-smds-fc18002-p │ │ │ │ It is also available as part of the Project User Defined Documentation, │ │ it can be accessed by selecting this module in the Project Tree │ │ (on the left) and pressing SHIFT+F1 │ │ │ └─────────────────────────────────────── ʷᴵᴰ⁻ᵈᶤᵇ ┘
FC18001_StdSubScaleAI is a subroutine block that is used to convert a scaled device signal to an integer signal being passed to an analog output in the form of an output word (QW).
The initial scaled value is a real (floating point) number that matches the calibrated range of the device in engineering units.
The block monitors the scaled signal to see if the scaled value is out-of-range, the following three fault signals are generated:
• Over-range (signal is more than a specified percentage above the calibrated range of the instrument
• Under-range (signal is more than a specified percentage below the calibrated range of the instrument
• Common out-of-range, either the over-range or under-range fault is active
This is a subroutine block.
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 1. BLOCK TECHNICAL SUMMARY
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― NOMENCLATURE & ADDRESSING ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― BLOCK TITLE Analog Output Scale BLOCK FUNCTION GROUP Subroutine BLOCK ADDRESS FC18002 BLOCK SYMBOL FC18002_StdSubScaleAQ BLOCK USER ID StdSubScaleAQ
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― BLOCK TYPE & USAGE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― BLOCK TYPE Function (FC) BLOCK NUMBER 18002 LANGUAGE LAD OPTIMISED ACCESS Yes PAL USAGE TYPE Standard block
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― METRICS ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― EXECUTION TIME 23.6 μs¹ LOAD MEMORY 30.5 kB WORK MEMORY 0.5 kB ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ¹ Measured on: CPU-1515-2PN (order no. 6ES7512-2AM02-0AB0) https://psop.uk/pal-ds-cpu1515
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ Additional document references
In addition to the documents referenced in OB1 (section DOCUMENT REFERENCES), the following documents are associated with this module:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― REF. DOCUMENT NO. TITLE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― 101 PS2001-5-2312-db00801 DB00802 (analog output raw data) SMDS 102 PS2001-5-2312-db00851 DB00852 (analog output scale data) SMDS ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 1. FUNCTIONAL DESCRIPTION
FC18002 is the Analog Output Scale block, it is a subroutine block designed to convert a scaled signal into a form suitable for an analog output it provides the following broad functions:
• Converts a scaled, floating point (real) number that reflects the output range of a device, into a raw integer signal for an analog output
• Generate fault signals if the instrument is out of range
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 1.1 Convert a scaled value into an analog output
The principal function of the block is to convert a scaled, floating point (real) number that reflects the output range of a device, into a raw integer signal for an analog output (in the form of an output word, QW).
For example, if a variable speed drive had a scaled operating range of 150 rpm to 1500 rpm and was driven via a 4-20 mA analog output signal from the PLC, then 4 mA would represent 150 rpm and 20 mA would represent 1500 rpm.
A typical 4-20 mA analog output signal has a raw value of 0 at 4 mA and 27648 at 20 mA.
The block would generate output values as follows (it would also return every value in between; five typical values have been shown):
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SCALED OUTPUT SIGNAL RAW INTEGER VALUE FOR OUTPUT ACTUAL OUTPUT SIGNAL ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― 150.0 rpm 0 4 MA 487.5 rpm 6,912 8 MA 825.0 rpm 13,824 12 MA 1162.5 rpm 20,736 16 MA 1500.0 rpm 27,648 20 MA ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 1.2 Fault signals
The block is able to generate three fault signals:
• Device is over-range
• Device is under-range
• Device is out-of-range (common signal)
Over-range and under-range faults are generated if the device is reading outside its normal calibrated range. Over-range if the device is reading higher than its maximum configured value and under-range if lower than its minimum configured value.
The levels at which the device is considered to be either over-range or under-range (out-of-range), are set as configurable values passed to the module.
The out-of-range fault signal is a common signal that activates if either the over-range or under-range signal is
All three signal activate if there is a configuration error with the data provided to the module (see § 2.1.2).
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 2. DETAILED BLOCK DESCRIPTION
This module, FC18001_StdSubScaleAI is a subroutine block that can be called from other blocks within the PAL. It is designed to provide a linear conversion of a scaled device output signal in engineering units (in real format) to an integer value that repre-sents the analog output value passed to an analog output card (as an integer).
These are the formal module parameters:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― PARAM FUNCTION TYPE IN-OUT ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL The scaled value of the device output in Real In engineering units
AQ_RAW_DATA Analog output signal configuration data (type, UT00802 In range, descriptions card parameters and coefficients)
AQ_SCALE_DATA Analog output signal scaled value data UT00852 In (instrument tag, range, descriptions and engineering units)
AQ_RAW_SIGNAL The actual analog output Word Out engineering units
OVER_RANGE Indicates the scaled signal is above its Bool Out calibrated range by more than the tolerance value
UNDER_RANGE Indicates the scaled signal is below its Bool Out calibrated range by more than the tolerance value
OUT_OF_RANGE Indicates the scaled signal is outside of its Bool Out calibrated range either over or under range ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Note: If a configuration error is present (see § 2.1.2) the three out of range parameters will be activated (set true) and the AI_SCALE_SIGNAL signal will be set to zero irrespective of the AI_RAW_SIGNAL value.
The AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL signal is provided directly from the module controlling the device and is a real number in engineering units (e.g. 1220.4 rpm).
The AQ_RAW_SIGNAL signal is the integer value passed directly to the specific output channel of the analog output card.
The AQ_RAW_DATA and AQ_SCALE_DATA parameters are UDTs that hold information about the nature of the AQ_RAW_SIGNAL. In the case of AQ_RAW_DATA it specifies the output type: voltage, current &c., its range in integer values, various par-ametric information and a textual description of the signal. In the case of AQ_SCALE_DATA it specifies the scaled range of the signal, its engineering units, out-of-range values, a textual description of the device and the device tag itself.
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― PARAM ASSOCIATED UDT ASSOCIATED DATA BLOCK ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_RAW_DATA UT00802_St_ConstAqRawData DB00802_St_ConstAqRawData AQ_SCALE_DATA UT00852_St_ConstAqScaleData DB00852_St_ConstAqScaleData ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
Section 2.1.1 contains a full description of the AQ_RAW_DATA and AQ_SCALE_DATA parameters.
AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL is the true scaled value of the signal being passed to the analog output (AQ_RAW_SIGNAL) in engineering units.
OVER_RANGE and UNDER_RANGE indicate if the scaled signal is outside its permitted range. The limits at which under-range and over-range faults activate are provided as part of the information supplied via the AQ_SCALE_DATA parameter.
OVER_RANGE indicates the output is higher than the permitted tolerance and UNDER_RANGE indicates the output is lower than the permitted tolerance.
OUT_OF_RANGE is simply a common signal indicating the either OVER_RANGE or UNDER_RANGE is active.
This arrangement conforms with the PAL philosophy where IO card connections, safety signals and interlocks have unique formal parameters; all remaining signals are passed as variables within UDTs, see the Software Design Specification [Ref 008].
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 2.1 Converting the scaled device signal to an analog output value
The AQ_RAW_SIGNAL is the raw device signal passed to the analog output card; this has specific ranges depending on the type of IO card and the type of signal in use.
The following table shows example ranges for the AI_RAW_SIGNAL signal:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― LOWER LIMIT EQUIVALENT UPPER LIMIT EQUIVALENT SIGNAL TYPE (RAW_MIN) TO (RAW_MAX) TO ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― -10 V to 10 V -27648 -10 V 27648 +10 V 0 V to 10 V 0 +10 V 27648 +10 V 1 V to 5 V 0 +1 V 27648 +5 V -20 mA to 20 mA -27648 -20 mA 27648 +20 mA 0 mA to 20 mA 0 0 mA 27648 +20 mA 4 mA to 20 mA (2/4w) 0 4 mA 27648 +20 mA ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Example ranges for an analog output signal
The RAW_MIN and the RAW_MAX values in the above tables are the numerical values for the analog output range; the appropriate values are supplied as the RAW_MIN and RAW_MAX variables provided in the UDT of parameter AQ_RAW_DATA. (see § 2.1.1 for a full description).
The corresponding values for the originating scaled device signal are similarly provided by the SCALE_MIN and SCALE_MAX values provided in the UDT of parameter AQ_SCALE_DATA (see § 2.1.1 for a full description).
Thus, if a variable speed drive had a scaled operating range of 150 rpm to 1500 rpm that was passed from the PLC as a 4 20 mA signal,
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION VALUE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_RAW_DATA.RAW_MIN RANGE — Minimum value of the raw analog 0 signal (at the card) AQ_RAW_DATA.RAW_MAX RANGE — Maximum value of the raw analog 27648 signal (at the card) AQ_SCALE_DATA.SCALE_MIN RANGE — Minimum value of the scaled analog 150 rpm signal [engineering units] AQ_SCALE_DATA.SCALE_MAX RANGE — Maximum value of the scaled analog 1500 rpm signal [engineering units] ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
The scaled value from the originating device is passed to the module as a real number in the parameter: AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL
The analog output signal (AQ_RAW_SIGNAL) is calculated as follows:
┌────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ (AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL ─ SCALE_MIN) ╳ (RAW_MAX ─ RAW_MIN) │ │AQ_RAW_SIGNAL = ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ┼ RAW_MIN │ │ (SCALE_MAX ─ SCALE_MIN) │ └────────────────────────────────────── (2.1) ───┘
In the above calculation, RAW_MIN and RAW_MAX are preceded by AQ_RAW_DATA. and SCALE_MIN and SCALE_MAX are preceded by AQ_SCALE_DATA.
The three signals: AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL, SCALE_MIN and SCALE_MAX are all floating-point numbers (real data type), the signals AQ_RAW_SIGNAL, RAW_MIN and RAW_MAX are all integers (int data type).
Note: It is assumed that the instrument has a linear response.
AQ_ SCALE_VALUE ↑ ⋰ SCALE_MAX__│______________________________________⋰ │ ╱| │ ╱ | │ ╱ | │ ╱ | │ ╱ | │ ╱ | │ ╱ | AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL │- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -> ╱ | │ ╱╎ | │ ╱ ╎ | │ ╱ ╎ | │ ╱ ╎ | │ ╱ ╎ | │ ╱ ╎ | │ ╱ ╎ | SCALE_MIN__│______╱ ╎ | │ ⋰| ╎ | │ ⋰ | ↓ | ┼─────────────────────────→ AQ_RAW_SIGNAL | ╎ | RAW_MIN ╎ RAW_MAX AQ_RAW_SIGNAL
Figure 2.1 Linear relationship between AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL and AQ_RAW_SIGNAL
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 2.1.1 Using AQ_RAW_DATA and AQ_SCALE_DATA
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ The AQ_RAW_DATA parameter
The parameter AQ_RAW_DATA is used to pass the analog output card type, range, and description data used by all analog output card channels. Data is supplied to this parameter using DB00802_St_ConstAqRawData, this contains a formal set of data for every type of Siemens analog output (datasets), E.g.: for a 4-wire 4-20 mA signal it is:
AQ_RAW_2002 "UT00802_St_ConstAqRawData" AQ Current (4 mA to 20 mA) revInfo "UT01000_St_SysRevision" ___________0010_0 Bool false ___________0010_1 Bool false AQ_CODE UInt 16#2002 ___________0020_0 Bool false ___________0020_1 Bool false RAW_MIN Int 0 RAW_MAX Int 27648 RAW_DESC String[60] 'Current (4 mA to 20 mA)' ___________0030_1 Bool false ___________0030_2 Bool false PARAM_TYPE Byte 16#02 PARAM_RANGE Byte 16#02
A full description of DB00801_St_ConstAiRawData and its associated datasets is given in [Ref. 101].
The primary in formation needed by the module are maximum and minimum ranges for the input signal, this information is given in in the variables:
AQ_RAW_DATA ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION TYPE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_RAW_DATA.RAW_MIN Minimum value of the analog input Int range being used by the module
AQ_RAW_DATA.RAW_MAX Maximum value of the analog input Int range being used by the module ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
These are the RAW_MIN and RAW_MAX values used in equation (2.1).
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ The AQ_SCALE_DATA parameter
The AQ_SCALE_DATA parameter is similar to the AI_RAW_DATA parameter except that in this case it holds the scaled range, instrument tag, signal description and as-sociated engineering unit information. Data is supplied to this parameter using DB00852_St_ConstAqScaleData, this contains a set of data each device configured for the project, each device being a dataset. E.g.
AQ_SCALE_FC001 "UT00852_Sy_ConstAqScaleData" revInfo "UT01000_St_SysRevision" ___________0010_0 Bool false ___________0010_1 Bool false AQ_TAG String[20] 'FC001' ___________0020_0 Bool false ___________0020_1 Bool false SCALE_MIN Real 0.0 SCALE_MAX Real 100.0 SCALE_UNITS String[20] '%' SCALE_DESC String[60] 'Inlet flow control valve (0 to 100%)' ___________0030_0 Bool false ___________0030_1 Bool false LIMIT_UNDER Real -2.2 LIMIT_OVER Real 102.5 ___________0040_0 Bool false ___________0040_1 Bool false USER_INFO_1 String[60] 'Instrument Manufacturer: Siemens' USER_INFO_2 String[60] 'Instrument type: 2-port magnetic' USER_INFO_3 String[60] 'Instrument part no.: MXG461.15-0.6' USER_INFO_4 String[60] 'Instrument serial no.:2075181118' USER_INFO_5 String[60] ''
A full description of DB00852_St_ConstAqScaleData and its application is given in [Ref. 102].
The primary in formation needed by the module are maximum and minimum ranges for the scaled signal, this information is given in in the AI_SCALE_DATA parameter:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION TYPE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_SCALE_DATA.SCALE_MIN Minimum value of the analog input Real range being used by the module
AQ_SCALE_DATA.SCALE_MAX Maximum value of the analog input Real range being used by the module ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
These are the SCALE_MIN and SCALE_MAX values used in (2.1).
Additionally, the instrument tag is contained in the variable
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION TYPE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_SCALE_DATA.AQ_TAG Tag name of the device String[20] ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 2.1.2 Configuration errors
The block requires that both the RAW_MAX/MIN and SCALE_MAX/MIN signals conform to certain rules:
1. RAW_MIN must be less than, and not equal to RAW_MAX 2. SCALE_MIN must be less than, and not equal to SCALE_MAX
Should either of these conditions not be met, the three out of range parameters will all be activated (set true)
OVER_RANGE UNDER_RANGE OUT_OF_RANGE
In addition, the AQ_RAW_SIGNAL signal will be set to zero irrespective of the AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL value.
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 2.2 Out of range signals
If the AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL signal is outside the SCALE_MIN to SCALE_MAX range (red dotted area of the graph, Figure 2.1), the AQ_RAW_VALUE will still be calculated correctly; however, an appropriate, OVER_RANGE or UNDER_RANGE signal will be generated to indicate that the AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL signal is outside the calibrated range of the instrument and is potentially no longer accurate.
Some tolerance is permitted before the OVER_RANGE and UNDER_RANGE signals are activated (most devices are tolerant of slight over and under shoot readings).
The limits at which an over-range or under-range signal is generated is specified in the dataset passed to the module in the AQ_SCALE_DATA parameter. Each such dataset is stored in DB00852_St_ConstAqScaleData (see § 2.1.1) in the variables LIMIT_OVER and LIMIT_UNDER respectively. These represent the highest and lowest values that the scaled instrument value can read without being either over-range or under-range:
AQ_SCALE_DATA ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION TYPE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― LIMIT_UNDER Lower limit of the scaled instrument value in Real engineering units before instrument is under-range
LIMIT_OVER Upper limit of the scaled instrument value in Real engineering units before instrument is over-range ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 2.2.1 Common out of range signal
There is a third out of range signal: OUT_OF_RANGE, this signal is a common signal that just indicates the device is out of its calibrated range (it does not specify whether it is over or under range).
It is activated if either the OVER_RANGE or UNDER_RANGE signal is active.
Note: If a configuration error exists, see § 2.1.2, all three out of range signals (OVER_RANGE, UNDER_RANGE and OUT_OF_RANGE) will be activated irrespective of the RAW_ANALOG value
▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁▁ 2.2.2 Over and under range restrictions
The out-of-range limits passed to the module (AQ_SCALE_DATA) must meet the following conditions:
• LIMIT_UNDER ≤ SCALE_MIN • LIMIT_OVER ≥ SCALE_MAX
I.e. the device cannot be considered either under range or over range if it is within the normal range of the device.
If the over-range limit (LIMIT_OVER) is less than SCALE_MAX, then it’s value will be replaced by SCALE_MAX in all calculations. Similarly, if the under-range limit (LIMIT_UNDER) is greater than SCALE_MIN, then it’s value will be replaced by SCALE_MIN in all calculations.
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━
Block description — Sections 1 to 2

▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 3. Supervisory system interface
FC18002 is a Subroutine block used to scale an analog input.
It does not have a supervisory system interface.
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 4. PARAMETERS
The following parameters are associated with this module:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― PARAM FUNCTION TYPE IN-OUT ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL The scaled value of the device output in Real In engineering units
AQ_RAW_DATA Analog output signal configuration data (type, UT00802 In range, descriptions card parameters and coefficients)
AQ_SCALE_DATA Analog output signal scaled value data UT00852 In (instrument tag, range, descriptions and engineering units)
AQ_RAW_SIGNAL The actual analog output Word Out engineering units
OVER_RANGE Indicates the scaled signal is above its Bool Out calibrated range by more than the tolerance value
UNDER_RANGE Indicates the scaled signal is below its Bool Out calibrated range by more than the tolerance value
OUT_OF_RANGE Indicates the scaled signal is outside of its Bool Out calibrated range either over or under range ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Note: If a configuration error is present (see § 2.1.2) the three out of range parameters will be activated (set true) and the AI_SCALE_SIGNAL signal will be set to zero irrespective of the AI_RAW_SIGNAL value.
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 5. DATA STRUCTURES AND USAGE
The block has the following associated data structure:
―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― DATA STRUCTURE DESCRIPTION ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― UT01000_St_SysRevision Revision information for this block See FC01001 UT01001_St_SysLicence Licence information for this block See FC01001
UT00802_St_ConstAqRawData Analog output signal configuration data (type, range, descriptions card parameters &c.)
UT00852_St_ConstAqScaleData Analog output signal scaled value data (instrument tag, range, descriptions and engineering units) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― Note: This subroutine does not require the system signals data interface (DB21001_Dy_SysSignals). The module is entirely autonomous.
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 5.1 UT00802_St_ConstAqRawData
The static data structure for an analog instrument.
UT00802_St_ConstAqRawData (full contents) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION TYPE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_CODE A 16-bit hex value that uniquely identifies dataset UInt (it is the variable name of the dataset in DB00802) RAW_MIN Minimum value of the raw analog signal Int (at the card)
RAW_MAX Maximum value of the raw analog signal Int RAW_DESC Textual plain English description of the channel String[60] type and range PARAM_TYPE An 8-bit hex code that represents the input type Byte See [Ref. 101]
PARAM_RANGE An 8-bit hex code that represents the input range Byte See [Ref. 101]
――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 5.2 UT00852_St_ConstAqScaleData
The static data structure for an analog instrument.
UT00852_St_ConstAqScaleDataa (full contents) ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SIGNAL NAME FUNCTION TYPE ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― AQ_TAG Tag name of the instrument String[20]
SCALE_MIN Minimum value of the scaled input signal range Real being used by the module SCALE_MAX Maximum value of the scaled input signal range Real being used by the module
SCALE_UNITS Engineering units for the instrument String[20] SCALE_DESC Textual plain English description of the instrument String[60]
LIMIT_UNDER Lower limit of the scaled instrument value in Real engineering units before instrument is under-range LIMIT_OVER Upper limit of the scaled instrument value in Real engineering units before instrument is over-range
USER_INFO_1 Optional user information (text) line 1 String[60] USER_INFO_2 Optional user information (text) line 2 String[60] USER_INFO_3 Optional user information (text) line 3 String[60] USER_INFO_4 Optional user information (text) line 4 String[60] USER_INFO_5 Optional user information (text) line 5 String[60] ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 6. CONSTANTS AND TEMPORARY (LOCAL) DATA
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 6.1 Constants

▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 7. BLOCK CALLS AND ASSOCIATIONS
This section details any blocks which may be called from within this software module (subroutine functions for example), any partner blocks with which it may be associated (for example a receive module that is partner with a transmit module &c.). It lists any system functions which may be called (e.g. reading the real time clock) and any system data types that may be used.
Finally, it lists any special calling requirements for the block (for example, must be called from within a cyclic interrupt organisation block) and if the block is using “optimised access” (this is the default arrangement).
▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂▂ 7.1 Block calls from within this module
There are no PAL block calls from within this block.

This is a stand-alone block and is not associated with any other blocks.

▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 8. EXAMPLE USAGE
The following shows a typical deployment of FC18002:
┌───────────── ───────────────┤ FC18002 ├─────────── │ │ "FCV001" ─┤ AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL │ │ │ "DB00802".AQ_RAW_2003 ─┤ AQ_RAW_DATA │ │ │ "DB00852".AQ_SCALE_FCV001 ─┤ AQ_SCALE_DATA │ │ │ AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL├─ #FCV001_RAW │ UNDER_RANGE ├─ #ALM_UNDER │ OVER_RANGE├─ #ALM_OVER │ OUT_OF_RANGE├─ #ALM_OOR │ ─────────────┘
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━
▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄ 9. TEST AND VERIFICATION PATH
The following diagram shows the full test and verification path for the formal release of each version of the software module. See the Test Plan [Ref. 003] for full details, available here: https://psop.uk/pal-tp-p
FC18002-T001
Test version: 000.801 Released version: 001.000 Released commit: D0018
SCR SMT ＿＿＿＿＿＿┌┐＿＿ ▛▜ ＿＿ └┘ ▙▟ Initial test
Initial test to release the module following the development stage. Full SMT
Where: ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――― SCR Source Code Review A visual inspection of the software to ensure it has been written ┌┐ to the correct standards, uses the correct structures within the └┘ software and is generally suitable for deployment.
SMT Software Module Test A full and detailed test of an individual software module in ▛▜ isolation; such testing requires that all branches of the ▙▟ software are tested.
It tests all the interfaces to the module, any data recorded or stored by the module, all error and exception handling functions and tests all timed and interrupt driven operations.
SMTp SMT partial retest A partial repeat of some aspect of the full SMT to retest a small ▛ ┐ change made to some aspect of the software. The change └ ▟ must be small, specific and localised.
SCV Software Compatibility A mechanism for verifying that no executable code software ╓╖ Verification changes have been made to a module following changes to ╙╜ comment fields.
Allows typographical errors &c. to be corrected without forcing a full SMT on a module that has not functionally changed. ――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――――
An SCV can only be performed on a module that has at some point previously, successfully completed both an SCR and SMT. Where an SCV is implemented, it replaces the requirement for both the SCR and the SMT for the test iteration in question.
━━━ ⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙⬙ ━━━

Block description — Sections 3 to 9

The revision data shown here, in the network comments, contains additional information reflecting the software development workflow under the version control system (VCS) employed to track all software changes.
The VCS in use is the Git Source Code Management system in conjunction with the GitHub online hosting system. The software in its entirety is available in the GitHub remote repository:
https://github.com/practicalseries/PS2001-pal-software
The repository is public and can be freely copied (forked in GitHub terminology) and used under the MIT licence.
The MIT licence is reproduced in full in the last network of this software module.

▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
Current revision and modification history

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ Determines if a configuration error has occurred, this is true if either the RAW range or SCALED range has not been specified correctly, either:
• RAW_MAX <= RAW_MIN (raw range error) OR • SCALE_MAX <= SCALE_MIN (scaled range error)
If either, or both, conditions are true, the wrkConfigError signal is activated ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
Configuration Error Check

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ The out-of-range limits passed to the module (AQ_SCALE_DATA) must meet the following conditions:
• LIMIT_UNDER ≤ SCALE_MIN • LIMIT_OVER ≥ SCALE_MAX
I.e. the instrument cannot be considered either under range or over range if it is within the normal range of the instrument.
If the over-range limit (LIMIT_OVER) is less than SCALE_MAX, then it’s value will be replaced by SCALE_MAX in all calculations. Similarly, if the under-range limit (LIMIT_UNDER) is greater than SCALE_MIN, then it’s value will be replaced by SCALE_MIN in all calculations.
The limits in use are stored in wrkLimitUnder and wrkLimitOver ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
Signal conditioning — Ensure Out of Range percentage is 10% or less

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ The following formula is used to calculate the raw analog output signal (AQ_RAW_SIGNAL): ┌────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ (AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL ─ SCALE_MIN) ╳ (RAW_MAX ─ RAW_MIN) │ │AQ_RAW_SIGNAL = ―――――――――――――――――――――――――――― ┼ RAW_MIN │ │ (SCALE_MAX ─ SCALE_MIN) │ └────────────────────────────────────────────┘
Rawvalue calculation part 1 is (AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL − SCALE_MIN) ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
IO evaluation — Analog output calculation - Part 1

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ Scale value calculation part 2 (SCALE_MAX − SCALE_MIN)
Note: To prevent inconsistencies and divide by zero errors, if a configuration error is present (resulting from incorrect range data and indicated by status_ConfigError = TRUE), the denominator of the calculation (CalPart2) is set to 3.402823 × 1038 (i.e. a very large number), the result of this is that the raw signa will equal RAW_MIN for all permitted values of AQ_SCALE_SIGNAL ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
IO evaluation —Analog output calculation - Part 2
IO evaluation — Analog output calculation - Part 3

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ (calPart1 x CalPart3) Complete the calculation SCALE_VALUE = —————————— + RAW_MIN calPart2
If a configuration error exists, the SCALE_VALUE is set to zero for all conditions ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
IO evaluation —Analog output calculation - Part 4

▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀▀ The device signal is over range if AQ_SCALED_SIGNAL is greater than wrkLimitOver
The instrument is under range if AQ_SCALED_SIGNAL is less than wrkLimitUnder
If either of these conditions is true, the common out of range signal is activated
Note: If the range information is incorrect (wrkConfigError = TRUE), Then all the out of range signals are activated (UNDER_RANGE, OVER_RANGE and OUT_OF_RANGE) simultaneously ▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄▄
IO evaluation — Out of range signals

LICENCE AND CONTACT INFORMATION
Standard Module [SUBROUTINE] — Analog Output Scale
